msgSnippet: So said  Lauren Bish  on  2/21/2003 -------------------- ... purpose ... helped ... door. I didn t realize that there was all this context around the issue, so
messageBody:
So said Lauren Bish on 2/21/2003 --------------------

>----- Original Message -----
>From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
>
>
>>
>> Hear, hear.
>>
>> The goal of Programmer Tests is to for the programmer to:
>>
>> * have tangible evidence of progress
>> * clarify the needs of the design
>> * "eat his own dog food" by being forced to write client code before
>> writing provider code
>> * keep focus on small steps
>> * avoid writing too much code in one flow
>>
>> I don't see how a dedicated unit tester can make that happen for a
>> programmer.
>
>That is all true - but I didn't say that a dedicated unit tester's
purpose
>was to replace TDD - what I said was that the dedicated unit tester
helped
>in getting more and better tests earlier. A dedicated unit tester also
>helps
>introduce the concept and value of unit and early testing to teams,
>management, companies and developers. This helps get your foot in the
door.

I didn't realize that there was all this context around the issue, so I
apologize if my entry into the discussion was off base.

>You have to remember that there are a lot of companies out there that
don't
>practice XP or even halfway decent practices, <snip />

Oh, I know. I've worked for them. I'm in the XPAdoption group, trying
to figure out how to change all that. I'm convinced that the only thing
to do is to start my own shop, but I don't have the business and
marketing knowledge to run it, nor do I have the funds to pay someone
else to run it on day one.

<snip />
>Early testing has a value all its own, whether it is accomplished by
TDD,
>or
>dedicated unit testers or both. <snip />

No argument there. My concern is that everyone wants to test, but not
everyone has the same goals. In this case, I think it's important to
identify each person's (role's?) goals, then partition the work in a
way that there is sufficient overlap for crosschecking, but not so much
that we're all doing Solo Testing, but duplicating effort.

In that vein, I place more value on a dedicated tester (someone with
Testing Skill) doing integration-or-bigger testing, and leave the
testing of individual units of work to the people building them.

The more tests, the merrier, but let's not all try to write the same
tests.
<snip />
>> I feel appropriately inspired. Let me write the article, then I'll
be
>> back. :)
>
>I don't see the need.

Others may see the need. :)

>As I said I don't see a conflict between TDD and
>independent unit testing. The two can coexist. The only danger I would
see
>with both coexisting is that the developer may adopt the attitude that
>since
>there is an independent unit tester, that there is no reason for
him/her to
>do TDD.

Perhaps that is the article that needs to be written.

<snip />
>If I had developers that wrote poor tests because they felt the unit
>testers
>would catch the bugs anyway, I would probably approach the situation
the
>same as if I had a developer who wrote poor code because testers would
>sooner or later find any bugs. If they couldn't be made to see the
wisdom
>of
>early testing and TDD, then I would probably replace them with someone
who
>did.

I might approach the situation by explaining that the tests in TDD are
not meant to test, but rather the guide the design. In that light,
surely outside testing looks like a good idea.

<snip />
>The original question was not about TDD vs. independent unit testing,
the
>original question was how do you justify either one to management and
>project teams.

This is where my ignorance shines. I don't know how to convince anyone
of anything, so I'm content to let others try to do it.

<snip />
>Also, as I said, don't make the mistake of hubris in thinking that TDD
is
>going to find all the bugs and that an independent unit tester
wouldn't
>find
>at least some also - I dare say that an independent unit tester would
>probably find numerous bugs. Hire me and I will prove it to you. ;-)

Well, of course TDD won't find all the bugs. TDD isn't about finding
bugs.
